articles.title: October Climate Changes in the Arctic
articles.author: Rick Thoman
articles.summary: October climate over most of the Arctic has changed dramatically in the past 50 years. Sea ice is the main driver of the profound changes in the Arctic during October due to the dramatic decline in sea ice and the cascading effects of ice loss. The 50-year change in October average temperature is dramatic, with the most warming in the areas of extensive ice loss (Fig. 2). The fraction of October precipitation that falls as snow (zero to 100 percent) has decreased over the northern Atlantic Arctic and the northern Bering and Chukchi seas. There is a tendency toward less October snow farther south.

articles.title: Scientists 'dismayed' as PM to speak on climate target
articles.author: Grace Crivellaro
articles.summary: Dozens of prominent scientists have written a letter to Anthony Albanese over Australia's emissions reduction targets. They are upset with the government's target of a 62 to 70 per cent cut in greenhouse gas emissions compared with 2005 levels by 2035. Deakin University Professor Euan Ritchie slammed the target as "grossly inadequate" and said it would jeopardise the survival and wellbeing of Australians. The support for Australia to host the 2026 United Nations Climate Change Conference in New York is overwhelming.

articles.title: Flooding reported at Inner Harbour
articles.author: Renato Marques
articles.summary: Flooding started in Macau's Inner Harbour area at 9:30 a.m. Super Typhoon Ragasa was approaching Macau at its closest distance. The flood was caused by the increase in the tidal level, which caused seawater to reach land. The Red Storm Surge warning continues into force.

articles.title: Climate change is not Australia's biggest environmental threat
articles.author: Leith van Onselen
articles.summary: Last week, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese unveiled Labor's long-awaited 2035 climate targets, which promises to reduce emissions by more than 62% and up to 70%. Australia is a tiny (1%) emitter on the global stage, compared to the world's top emitters.

articles.title: ‘Green scam': At UN, watched by drowning nations' leaders, Trump assails the ethos of climate change
articles.author: Wtop
articles.summary: Some countries' leaders are watching rising seas threaten to swallow their homes. Others are watching their citizens die in floods, hurricanes and heat waves exacerbated by climate change. U.S. President thinks climate change is the greatest con job ever perpetrated on the world, in his opinion.

articles.title: At the United Nations, World Leaders Gathered for a Special Climate Summit
articles.summary: Floods in South Asia, wildfires across North America and record-breaking heat in Europe have underscored what scientists have warned for years: climate change is escalating faster than the political response. UN Secretary-General is holding a climate summit during the high-level week of the General Assembly, pressing nations to raise their climate pledges ahead of November's UN climate conference in Belém.

articles.title: Not a Myth Anymore
articles.summary: According to NASA, Earth's surface temperature has risen by 1.3°C above the 20th-century average due to human activity. Arctic ice has declined by over 2 million square kilometres since 1980. Global sea levels have risen by more than 90 millimetres since 1993.

articles.title: At UN, Trump attacks climate change efforts in front of leaders of drowning nations
articles.author: MELINA WALLING
articles.summary: Some countries' leaders are watching rising seas threaten to swallow their homes. Others are watching their citizens die in floods, hurricanes and heat waves, all exacerbated by climate change. "This 'climate change,' it's the greatest con job ever perpetrated on the world," Trump says.

articles.title: Study shows over half of world's coastal settlements relocating due to rising seas
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Settlements worldwide are shifting inland as sea levels rise, new research shows. 56 percent of coastal settlements relocated further inland, 28 percent stayed put and 16 percent moved closer to the shore. Settlements advanced most towards coastlines in South America and Asia. Oceania has some of the closest settlements to the coast globally.

articles.title: Vietnam issues ban on vessels going to sea as typhoon Ragasa approaches
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Quang Ninh, Ninh Binh, Hung Yen and Nghe An provinces imposed the ban starting at noon on Wednesday. Aquaculture workers in low-lying areas along rivers and coastal zones had to be relocated before 6 p.m. local time. Typhoon Ragasa weakened to level 14 from level 15 and is moving toward the eastern mainland.

articles.title: Global coastal ecosystems undergoing varying degrees of degradation: report
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Global Coastal Ecosystem Status Report was released at the 2025 World Coastal Forum in east China's Jiangsu Province. Seagrass beds, coral reefs, mollusk reefs and kelp forests have suffered the heaviest losses. Coastal urbanization, seawater warming and acidification due to climate change are the main factors leading to the degradation of coastal ecosystems.

articles.title: Ahead of New York climate summit, Climate Watch flags huge emissions gap
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: There is an 18.9 gigatonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (GtCO2e) gap to keep warming under 2°C and a 29.9 Gt CO2e under 1.5°C over pre-industrial levels, according to a Climate Watch analysis.

articles.title: Scientists weigh giant sea curtain to shield ‘Doomsday Glacier' from melting
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: Thwaites Glacier rises above the Amundsen Sea in the Antarctic. Thwaites is 120 km (80 miles) across and is part of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet. It's known as the 'Doomsday glacier' among scientists. It is roughly the size of Great Britain.

articles.title: The ‘Green Revolution' transformed global agriculture. Now it's adapting to climate change.
articles.author: Grist
articles.summary: Temperatures reached a record-breaking 127 degrees Fahrenheit in Haryana, India in 2022. The scorching heat shrivelled the wheat and forced it to mature faster, leading to half of Pritam Singh's wheat crop being destroyed. The per-acre wheat production in 2024 exceeded all expectations.

articles.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa: scientists warn climate change leads to stronger storms
articles.author: South China Morning Post
articles.summary: Super Typhoon Ragasa lashed Hong Kong and the southern Chinese province of Guangdong on Wednesday. Scientists warn that climate change is making such weather patterns more likely.    in response to the typhoon's impact on the region.  in this way.

articles.title: Countries demand urgent action after Trump's dismissal of climate change at UNGA
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: Donald Trump dismissed climate change as "the greatest con job ever". Several countries warn that ignoring science risks "irreversible catastrophe" as we approach the 1.5 degrees Celsius threshold and warn that tipping points threaten to throw the planet into an even greater and irreversible catastrophe.

articles.title: US Commodity Markets Brace for Stormy Horizon: Extreme Weather and Hurricanes Threaten Agriculture and Energy
articles.author: The Call
articles.summary: The U.S. is bracing for an above-average hurricane season for 2025 and an ongoing barrage of extreme weather events. The confluence of climatic challenges is expected to ripple through the nation's vital agricultural and energy commodity markets. The weather events are poised to significantly impact the agriculture and energy markets.

articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: Atlantic Canada was hit hard by a heat wave in August. Some scientists say it's more likely caused by human-induced climate change than natural weather patterns.   Â      in the past year. In the past few years, the number of heatwaves in Atlantic Canada has increased.

articles.title: Airports will get noisier due to climate change say scientists
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Scientists have discovered that warmer air from climate change will create more noise pollution from departing airplanes around European airports. On average, departing aircraft climb on average on average as a result of the rising air temperature. The research was carried out by researchers from the University of Reading.
